Understate: The claim understates the actual cost of the shutdown by only mentioning the $11 billion estimate without explaining that the economy is expected to regain $8 billion of that this year.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the $11 billion estimate.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the $11 billion estimate is the total cost of the shutdown without considering other factors or indirect economic costs.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim leaves out the other part of the Congressional Budget Office's analysis, which states that the economy is expected to regain $8 billion and that $3 billion in forgone economic activity will not be recovered.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the Congressional Budget Office estimates the actual cost of the shutdown to be $3 billion, not $11 billion.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the cost of the shutdown by using the $11 billion estimate without providing the full context of the CBO's analysis.
